Strategies for implementation. Cyclone. Ware house in place and preposition stock in place before disaster is a rely good practice as it gives the capacities to VRCS to respond in a timely and effective manner
Water Sanitation and Hygiene. Fire. WASH activities were also suspended due to social unrest and had to be rescheduled to complete the intervention
Water Sanitation and Hygiene. Civil Unrest. Water providers were reluctant to engage their vehicle in such activities due to the risk of damaging and/or losing their vehicle.
Health. Flood. We learned that it will be important to have more infrastructure and equipment, as well as didactic materials for PSS activities (for drawing and painting, etc.).

Protection, Gender and Inclusion. Flood. We must find a way for these topics to be better accepted and applied by staff.  Social Inclusion Policy Social Inclusion Strategy Gender Equality and Equity Promotion Policy at Costa Rican Red Cross.
Shelter and Settlements. Cyclone. Weak coordination in Nord Ouest of the stakeholders at the departmental level resulted in difficulties in carrying out the joint assessments
Water Sanitation and Hygiene. Cyclone. Weather (rainy) affected coverage

Water Sanitation and Hygiene. Cyclone. Weather conditions during the distribution of the items were not favorable during the response period which affected the ability of FRCS team to reach communities that can only assessed by boat. This contributed to the low number of items distributed to affected families.
Health. Epidemic. Weekly skype meetings with branches for reporting and planning should be set up

Shelter and Settlements. Volcanic Eruption. Well-coordinated response through the VRCS ERT volunteer network in communities and province and also good working relationship with ACS thus making distribution and Assessment easier

Shelter and Settlements. Cyclone. Well-coordinated response through the VRCS ERT volunteer network in communities and province and also good working relationship with ACS thus making distribution and Assessment easier.

Water Sanitation and Hygiene. Flood. Well cleaning programmes field implementation were quite challenging, especially in the process of finding required equipment (water pumps, ladders with different heights) and in some areas, electricity supply was also disrupted. This affected well cleaning work in areas where water pumps were operated with electricity.

Strategies for implementation. Flood. When a disaster occurs, it is important to contact partners as early as possible and involve them in the planning of the operation in order to motivate them to participate. Moreover, it is also encouraging for the partners to respect the set deadlines. Therefore, the NS should strive to stick to its schedule as much as possible

Strategies for implementation. Flood. When a disaster occurs, it is important to contact partners as early as possible and involve them in the planning of the operation in order to motivate them to participate. Moreover, it is also encouraging for the partners to respect the set deadlines. Therefore, the NS should strive to stick to its schedule as much as possible

Health. Epidemic. When community-based disease surveillance works well, cholera and other epidemic diseases are identified at an early stage and the disease is easily controlled. It is thus important to strengthen the capacity of community-based disease surveillance agents especially at border level
Strategies for implementation. Epidemic. When conducting a large scale project in short time period, lot of human resoruces are needed. Therefore its good to apoint volunteers for each program.

Health. Flood. When floods disaster occurs, response activities should include distribution of Mosquito nets, provision of water treatment or water purification tablets and the disinfection of well water as the most urgent activities in order to avoid the spread of diseases and epidemic outbreaks.

Health. Flood. When floods hit Dar es Salaam city, TRCS volunteers conducted emergency needs assessment in more than 10 wards that were severely affected by floods. However, the NS targeted two wards out of 10. This brought forward complaints to the NS. The branch addressed it through an explanation that the NS targets the most vulnerable communities and the ENA report was shared as part of evidence –base clarification to maintain the NS acceptance and visibility in the community.

Health. Epidemic. When it came to identification of fokontanys, in some regions and districts local branches did not exist. It took a long time to reactivate these local branches and identify volunteers

Livelihoods and Basic Needs . Cold Wave. When mid-level branches request their local registration offices for updated herder lists, it takes around 3-5 working days to grant an access to information. Forming an agreement/ MoU with National Registration Office at Headquarter level to give MRCS quick access to herder household lists during emergency times, will reduce the beneficiary registration time

Water Sanitation and Hygiene. Drought. When there is a wide geographic dispersal of families, community sessions should be held in the areas with the largest groupings of families, individual sessions should be held for areas with the greatest population dispersion and graphic materials should with instruction on the potabilization of water at the household level should be pasted on water buckets.
Health. Transport Accident. Where possible, material support should be considered to reduce family conflicts.
Health. Civil Unrest. While first aid is a strength of the BRC, PSS is a relatively new service. This needs to be further developed as part of the services provided to the community.

Water Sanitation and Hygiene. Volcanic Eruption. While in Maewo there were also issues with water source acceptance, even though clean water was readily available this often came from rivers and streams – many of the Ambae evacuees were used to using tank water and rain water and expressed their concerns and fears with using river water. VRCS volunteers would encourage water boiling and other household water treatment methods to reduce the concern among evacuees.
Livelihoods and Basic Needs . Flood. While planning activities for 2019 it is essential to review the floods contingency plan;

Disaster Risk Reduction and Climate Action. Civil Unrest. While teams across the country remained on standby, posting of some team members did not consider individual acceptance due to ethnicity during initial response on 8 August 2017. This meant that surge capacities had to be deployed late into the response to support ongoing responses in other regions.
Health. Flood. While the BRC had adequate health promotion materials for the activity, they should be distributed among the target communities at the beginning of the operation to save time.

Strategies for implementation. Civil Unrest. While the internal reflections among the various response teams helped coordinate activities better, there is need to organize much more formalized sessions to specifically review how the teams conducted themselves before, during and after the elections. Value for Money aspects similarly need to be evaluated using the approved Value for Money (VfM) matrix.

Strategies for implementation. Flood. Whilst coordination between IFRC and PNS was consistent, there is a need to ensure that consistent information and reporting provided to both IFRC and PNS from LRC. To ensure clear understanding of needs and requests for support

Strategies for implementation. Flood. Whilst coordination between IFRC and PNS was consistent, there is a need to ensure that consistent information and reporting provided to both IFRC and PNS from LRC. To ensure clear understanding of needs and requests for support

Protection, Gender and Inclusion. Cyclone. Whilst SADD information was collected during assessments and distribution of relief items, the level of detail did not always include all details in relation to vulnerability – elderly, pregnant and lactating women, PLWD.

Shelter and Settlements. Volcanic Eruption. Whilst VRCS worked closely with the NDMO to coordinate the response, there is a need for more open dialogue to be taking place with the government at the national level to ensure a quality response operation.
Strategies for implementation. Epidemic. With RDRT joining later, communication improved
Shelter and Settlements. Flood. With regards to the above report, it is important to preposition emergency items in Niger for a rapid and efficient intervention in case of emergency response.

Strategies for implementation. Flood. With support from national headquarters, IFRC and other partners, the Kerala State Branch has embarked on an extensive programme for training staff and volunteers, both to support the ongoing operations and to be better prepared for any future disasters.

Strategies for implementation. Cyclone. With the pandemic situation, it has changed the way for VRCS to response to disasters. VRCS have to review existing SOPs, come up with specific and very detailed contingency plan and review the National Society Disaster Management Plan.

Shelter and Settlements. Earthquake. Without the support of AmCross we would not have been able to assist the population;
Health. Other. Work in perfect collaboration with local authorities so that the population is always informed of the evolution of activities and especially involve the populations concerned
Livelihoods and Basic Needs . Drought. Work on a detailed initial assessment.
Livelihoods and Basic Needs . Drought. Work on the ODK survey sheets with enough time to make as few changes as possible once in the field, along with training on the tool's use

Shelter and Settlements. Flood. Work out the way to provide cash transfers to the affected population instead of distribution of NFIs in order to improve the quality and effectiveness of the provided relief in future operations.

Shelter and Settlements. Population Movement. Working in collaboration with the Congolese Armed forces delayed Red Cross work as it was not possible to operate concomitantly with them. Thirty-three (33) emergency shelters were not constructed because of the involvement of the Congolese Armed Forces in the process.
Livelihoods and Basic Needs . Flood. Working in hand with the local authorities and partners to avoid duplication of support
Water Sanitation and Hygiene. Flood. Working together with the communities enables people to learn the appropriate techniques and tools to enhance their preparedness for emergencies.
Health. Epidemic. Working with locally recruited community volunteers would bring an added value and efficiency to future operations, as they better understand the terrain than anyone else.
Strategies for implementation. Flood. Yearly contingency stock planning and fundraising for the stock through the RRCS HQ
Strategies for implementation. Flood. Yearly disaster planning in prevention and preparedness activities

Strategies for implementation. Epidemic. Zimbabwe Red Cross Society held a two-days Lessons learnt workshop of the DREF operation from the 11th to the 12th of December 2018. The lessons learnt workshop aimed at reviewing progress of the DREF activities and then looking at the gaps or challenges in the operation and what could be learned from the operation. As part of the workshop, the Africa Cholera framework was also presented as a way of introducing a new way of looking at Cholera responses in Africa. Participants at the Workshop were drawn from the Red Cross provinces and HQ. Participants included Provincial Programme Managers, Volunteer supervisors at the centre of the operation; ZRCS programme staff, PNS reps and IFRC Africa Region representative. (Health)
